dublin_core.dcvalue: Oral sex presents HIV risks and the safest method is to use a condom If that option is not chosen touching should be limited to only the penile shaft and testicles and oral contact with the penis s head should be avoided Preseminal and seminal fluids may contain HIV as might saliva but in lower concentrations The presence of blood in saliva caused by cuts or lacerations increases the risk of infection Using poppers also increases risk since they cause a concentration of white blood cells in oral mucous membranes Oral sex is considered less risky for the insertive partner than the receptive partner because the receptive partner is only exposed to a partner s saliva Phone numbers for safer sex information are provided
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T18:17:45Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 1996-04-23

[Oral sex without a condom--is it safe or not?].
